awd_titl_txt: The Impact of Toxicological Standards on Governance
awd_abstract_narration:
This historical study examines how toxicologists and regulators developed Good Laboratory
Practice (GLP) regulations to ensure the reliability of toxicology data supporting drug and
chemical regulation and trade. The study?s central goal is to understand how toxicological data have traveled out of the laboratory and across political jurisdictions.  The study traces how GLP rules that initially crafted to resolve a crisis in toxicology were used to regulate domestic and international chemical testing and trade. This study will contribute to our understanding of the interaction of trade and public health regulations. This study will help to evaluate impacts on public health and develop more effective policies.


This study seeks to understand how and why GLP was developed in the U.S., and why GLP appeared to OECD states to be a good solution to the problem of regulatory harmonization and facilitation of international trade. It asks how a particular way of doing laboratory
work was rendered authoritative, and what consequences this has had in governmental efforts to
control chemicals. The investigators will analyze archival records and published documents from regulatory agencies, toxicologists, and international standard-setting bodies, and conduct oral histories with participants. Findings from the study will inform the literature in the field of STS on the history of toxicology and risk analysis, the development of regulatory policies, and values in science.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation project investigates why governments have failed to regulate chemicals that are widely considered to be toxic. It demonstrates that governments have failed to act in part because of data standards created in the 1970s to govern how laboratories conduct drug and chemical safety testing--standards that have just as much to do with economics as the science of toxicity.

In the United States, the federal government has regulated chemicals in some form for most of the 20th century. However, in the 1970s, the revelation that fraudulent studies had been submitted to U.S. regulatory agencies cast doubt on the integrity of chemical safety data--and hence the safety of approved drugs, pesticides, and other chemical products. U.S. regulators responded by formulating quality assurance and reporting standards called Good Laboratory Practice (GLP). The rules were ostensibly adopted to assure the integrity of toxicology data; but, as this research demonstrates, agencies knew they would never achieve this goal. The aim was not to make laboratory practices good, but rather to make laboratory practices governable.

This approach was then adopted by the twenty-four industrialized nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) as part of its Mutual Acceptance of Data framework. At stake in this project is a critical examination of the political, intellectual, and scientific systems that serve as the basis for how governments around the world--to date, forty-one countries use the framework--know and regulate chemical products. In our research, we show that while the OECD did hope to protect public safety by ensuring data quality, their primary aim was to facilitate international trade by creating uniform standards. OECD nations sought to harmonize regulatory research--an important thread in the late 20th century globalization of both science and trade--by creating a bureaucratic process for attesting to the acceptability of chemical data.

The research illustrates how a question that was previously understood as the domain of science--how do we determine if this chemical is safe?--became reframed as a matter of economic policy. Crucial decisions about scientific matters became part of a complex nexus of issues at the intersection of commodity trade, regulation, and safety. We conclude that, since the 1970s, the aims of bureaucratic efficiency and free-flowing trade have driven the development of norms and practices that constitute how governments know and regulate risk. Based on oral history interviews and archival research conducted in a dozen archives around the U.S. and Paris, France, this study demonstrates how regulators came to trust standardized guideline studies over non-standardized but peer-reviewed ones. Because regulators' reliance on a particular knowledge production practice--uniform standardized protocols--constrained the evidence and expertise used to govern health, it impeded the uptake of knowledge in ways that benefitted business and government, but not necessarily the citizens whose health the state is charged with protecting. In short, it created an inability to know and act on knowledge produced outside those rigid protocols. It also made it difficult for regulators to adjust regulations in light of evolving scientific understandings. Our research demonstrates how the demands of free trade in the late 20th and early 21st centuries have contributed to undermining public health and safety.
